title: Creating Experiments
text: Creating experiment() object like assembling puzzle ‚Äì need three key pieces make everything fit together perfectly: Expression Matrix: numeric data arranged variables rows samples columns (heart dataset!) Sample Information: tibble containing juicy details samples ‚Äì groups, batches, demographics, name Variable Information: tibble describing variables ‚Äì proteins, peptides, glycan compositions, ‚Äôll also sprinkle experiment metadata complete picture. Ready? Let‚Äôs dive !

title: Creating Experiments
text: Let‚Äôs start sample information ‚Äì think sample‚Äôs ID card plus important details one. golden rule simple: first column must named sample, every entry needs unique (duplicates allowed!). sample identifiers ‚Äì names tie everything together. remaining columns, complete freedom! Add information matters analysis: groups, batches, patient demographics, treatment conditions ‚Äì whatever helps tell story.

title: Creating Experiments
text: glycoverse family favorite column names make everything work seamlessly: group: experimental conditions treatments (yes, make factor!). star player ‚Äì glystats functions rely column. batch: tracking sample batches (another factor, please!). Essential glyclean::remove_batch_effect(). batch column? problem ‚Äì glyclean::auto_clean() simply skip batch correction. bio_rep: biological replicates (factor!). May used future. Note: ‚Äôre constantly expanding list, stay tuned conventions! Another note: ‚Äúaccidentally‚Äù perfectly follow column typing conventions, function automatically coerce column types expected types. behavior can controlled coerce_col_types check_col_types arguments. Although can rely automatic column type conversion, still recommend manually convert column types expected types. allows finer control details, example, factor levels. Let‚Äôs build sample information table:
code: sample_info <- tibble(   sample = c("S1", "S2", "S3", "S4", "S5", "S6"),   group = factor(c("A", "A", "A", "B", "B", "B"), levels = c("A", "B")),   batch = factor(c(1, 2, 1, 2, 1, 2), levels = c(1, 2)) ) sample_info #> # A tibble: 6 √ó 3 #>   sample group batch #>   <chr>  <fct> <fct> #> 1 S1     A     1     #> 2 S2     A     2     #> 3 S3     A     1     #> 4 S4     B     2     #> 5 S5     B     1     #> 6 S6     B     2

title: Creating Experiments
text: Now variable information ‚Äì describe measurement actually represents. Good news glycoproteomics folks: ‚Äôre using glyread, sit back relax! automatically extracts information software output files. glycomics experiments: ‚Äôll likely need build manually, don‚Äôt worry ‚Äì glycomics data structures much straightforward glycoproteomics cousins.

title: Creating Experiments
text: Just like samples, first column must named variable unique values. ‚Äôs thing though ‚Äì names don‚Äôt need fancy meaningful. fact, glyread happily uses simple names like ‚ÄúV1‚Äù, ‚ÄúV2‚Äù, ‚ÄúV3‚Äù default, works perfectly fine!

title: Creating Experiments
text: glycomics experiments, columns friends: glycan_composition: Required. glycan composition glyrepr::glycan_composition() object glycan_structure: Optional. glycan structure glyrepr::glycan_structure() object (use character strings glyparse::auto_parse() understands, recommend parsed objects avoid repetitive parsing later) glycoproteomics experiments, ‚Äôll want additional columns: protein: Required. UniProt accession (character) protein_site: Required. Glycosylation site position protein (integer) gene: Optional. Gene name (character) peptide: Optional. Peptide sequence (character) peptide_site: Optional. Peptide site position glycan attachment (integer) Let‚Äôs create variable information table:
code: var_info <- tibble(   variable = c("V1", "V2", "V3"),   glycan_composition = glyrepr::glycan_composition(     c(GalNAc = 1),     c(Gal = 1, GalNAc = 1),     c(Gal = 1, GalNAc = 1, GlcNAc = 1)   ),   glycan_structure = glyrepr::as_glycan_structure(c(     "GalNAc(a1-",     "Gal(b1-3)GalNAc(a1-",     "Gal(b1-3)[GlcNAc(a1-6)]GalNAc(a1-"   )) ) var_info #> # A tibble: 3 √ó 3 #>   variable glycan_composition       glycan_structure                  #>   <chr>    <comp>                   <struct>                          #> 1 V1       GalNAc(1)                GalNAc(a1-                        #> 2 V2       Gal(1)GalNAc(1)          Gal(b1-3)GalNAc(a1-               #> 3 V3       Gal(1)GlcNAc(1)GalNAc(1) Gal(b1-3)[GlcNAc(a1-6)]GalNAc(a1-

title: Creating Experiments
text: Time main event ‚Äì expression matrix! actual measurements live. layout straightforward: variables rows, samples columns. don‚Äôt need perform transformation data, especially log-transformation. glycoverse functions handle data transformation internally needed.

title: Creating Experiments
text: ‚Äôs important bit: row names must match variable column variable information, column names must match sample column sample information. Think connecting dots data metadata. Bonus: order doesn‚Äôt need perfect ‚Äì functions smart enough line everything correctly! Let‚Äôs create expression matrix:
code: # Create a simple matrix with 3 variables and 6 samples expr_mat <- matrix(   rnorm(18, mean = 10, sd = 2), # Some realistic-looking data   nrow = 3,    ncol = 6 ) rownames(expr_mat) <- var_info$variable colnames(expr_mat) <- sample_info$sample expr_mat #>           S1        S2       S3        S4        S5       S6 #> V1  7.199913  9.988857 6.356365  9.434589 14.130050 6.273977 #> V2 10.510634 11.243105 9.505349  8.892601  6.738021 8.955975 #> V3  5.125473 12.296823 9.511601 11.257964 11.024854 9.894796

title: Creating Experiments
text: Congratulations! ‚Äôve got pieces puzzle. Now let‚Äôs assemble experiment() object: Don‚Äôt forget metadata: ‚Äôll need specify experiment type ("glycomics" "glycoproteomics") glycan type (like "N" N-linked, "O" O-linked, etc.). little details help downstream functions understand exactly ‚Äôre working . ‚Äì experiment() object, ready exciting analyses await! üéâ
code: exp <- experiment(expr_mat, sample_info, var_info, exp_type = "glycomics", glycan_type = "N") exp #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Glycomics Experiment ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ #> ‚Ñπ Expression matrix: 6 samples, 3 variables #> ‚Ñπ Sample information fields: group <fct>, batch <fct> #> ‚Ñπ Variable information fields: glycan_composition <comp>, glycan_structure <struct>

title: Creating Experiments
text: fact, minimum required input expression matrix. information provided, automatically generated based following rules: sample_info: tibble one column named ‚Äúsample‚Äù, column names expr_mat. var_info: tibble one column named ‚Äúvariable‚Äù, row names expr_mat. exp_type: ‚Äúothers‚Äù glycan_type: NULL means can create experiment() objects flexible way: first create backbone using expression matrix, add information later using mutate_var() mutate_obs(). multiple fields stored different tables, can use left_join_var() left_join_obs() join experiment().
code: expr_mat <- matrix(runif(9), nrow = 3, ncol = 3) colnames(expr_mat) <- c("S1", "S2", "S3") rownames(expr_mat) <- c("V1", "V2", "V3") experiment(expr_mat) #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Others Experiment ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ #> ‚Ñπ Expression matrix: 3 samples, 3 variables #> ‚Ñπ Sample information fields: none #> ‚Ñπ Variable information fields: none

Miss beat, symphony turns chaos. glyexp‚Äôs dplyr-style functions different. ‚Äôre like magical conductor‚Äôs baton - wave , three instruments respond perfect harmony! Let‚Äôs see magic action:

title: dplyr-Style Functions: Data Harmony in Action
text: Every dplyr-style function glyexp comes two delicious flavors: _obs() functions: Work sample information (observations/columns) experiment() objects _var() functions: Work variable annotations (variables/rows) experiment() objects ‚Äôs beautiful part - flavors automatically update expression matrix maintain perfect synchronization! ‚ö†Ô∏è Reminder: specialized functions require experiment() object input return experiment() object output. used standard tibbles data.frames - , use regular dplyr functions directly.

You should not explicitly select or deselect the "sample" column in #>   `sample_info`. #> ‚Ñπ The "sample" column will be handled by `select_obs()` or `select_var()` #>   automatically. get_sample_info(protective_exp) #> Error: object 'protective_exp' not found # Same protection for variable info protective_var_exp <- select_var(toy_exp, -variable) #> Error: #> ! title: dplyr-Style Functions: Data Harmony in Action
text: glyexp provides dplyr-style equivalents favorite data manipulation functions. function comes _obs() _var() flavors, automatically maintain matrix synchronization. üîß Technical Note: functions methods specifically experiment() objects. Unlike generic dplyr functions work various data types, functions expect return experiment() objects exclusively:

title: dplyr-Style Functions: Data Harmony in Action
text: Let‚Äôs explore function family hands-examples!

title: dplyr-Style Functions: Data Harmony in Action
text: Pro tip: Use dplyr-style helpers like starts_with(), ends_with(), contains():
code: # Select specific columns from sample info selected_exp <- select_obs(toy_exp, group, batch) get_sample_info(selected_exp) #> # A tibble: 6 √ó 3 #>   sample group batch #>   <chr>  <chr> <dbl> #> 1 S1     A         1 #> 2 S2     A         2 #> 3 S3     A         1 #> 4 S4     B         2 #> 5 S5     B         1 #> 6 S6     B         2 # Select columns from variable info (notice the index protection!) var_selected_exp <- select_var(toy_exp, glycan_composition) get_var_info(var_selected_exp) #> # A tibble: 4 √ó 2 #>   variable glycan_composition #>   <chr>    <chr>              #> 1 V1       H5N2               #> 2 V2       H5N2               #> 3 V3       H3N2               #> 4 V4       H3N2 # Select columns starting with "glycan" helper_exp <- select_var(toy_exp, starts_with("glycan")) get_var_info(helper_exp) #> # A tibble: 4 √ó 2 #>   variable glycan_composition #>   <chr>    <chr>              #> 1 V1       H5N2               #> 2 V2       H5N2               #> 3 V3       H3N2               #> 4 V4       H3N2

title: Experiment Types
text: ‚Äôs things get uniquely glycoverse! traitomics traitproteomics special experiment types emerge transform data using glydet::derive_traits() glymotif::quantify_motifs(). Starting traitomics: feed glycomics experiment derive_traits(), get back traitomics experiment. Instead measuring individual glycans sample, ‚Äôre now looking derived traits‚Äîthink higher-level summary glycan data. variable information table pretty flexible ‚Äîmandatory columns. However, ‚Äôll typically see: trait column (using derive_traits()) motif column (using quantify_motifs())

title: Experiment Types
text: Last least, traitproteomics‚Äîsophisticated experiment types. apply derive_traits() glycoproteomics experiment, get traitproteomics experiment back. ‚Äôs key insight: instead tracking individual glycans protein site, ‚Äôre now measuring derived traits site. Think glycosylation site little glycome, ‚Äôre summarizing characteristics mini-glycome. Essential columns variable information table: protein: protein UniProt accession (character string) protein_site: glycosylation site position (integer) Plus ‚Äôll get: trait column (derive_traits()) motif column (quantify_motifs()) ‚Äôs key difference: glycoproteomics, different sites can completely different glycan repertoires. traitproteomics, every site gets scored set traits motifs‚Äî‚Äôs like standardized metrics across glycosylation sites.

what: Do you need to worry about experiment types?

Important warning: ‚Äôve created experiment object, resist temptation manually fiddle exp_type field. break implicit contract data glycoverse functions‚Äînobody wants !

title: Create a new experiment ‚Äî experiment
code: experiment(   expr_mat,   sample_info = NULL,   var_info = NULL,   exp_type = "others",   glycan_type = NULL,   coerce_col_types = TRUE,   check_col_types = TRUE,   ... )  is_experiment(x)

title: Create a new experiment ‚Äî experiment
text: expr_mat expression matrix samples columns variables rows. sample_info tibble column named "sample", columns useful information samples, e.g. group, batch, sex, age, etc. NULL (default), tibble one column named "sample" created, column names expr_mat. var_info tibble column named "variable", columns useful information variables, e.g. protein name, peptide, glycan composition, etc. NULL (default), tibble one column named "variable" created, row names expr_mat. Must provided exp_type "others". exp_type type experiment, "glycomics", "glycoproteomics", "traitomics", "traitproteomics", "others". Default "others". glycan_type type glycan, "N" "O". Can NULL exp_type "others". coerce_col_types common column types coerced. Default TRUE. TRUE, columns "Column conventions" section coerced expected types. Skipped "others" type even TRUE. check_col_types column type conventions checked. Default TRUE. Type checking performed column coercion (coerce_col_types TRUE). Skipped "others" type even TRUE. ... meta data experiment. x object check.

title: Create a new experiment ‚Äî experiment
text: experiment(). input data wrong, error raised. logical value.

title: Create a new experiment ‚Äî experiment
text: Expression matrix: Must numeric matrix variables rows samples columns. column names must correspond sample IDs. row names must correspond variable IDs. Sample information (sample_info): Must tibble column named "sample" (sample ID). value "sample" must unique. set "sample" values must match column names expression matrix (order matter). Variable information (var_info): Must tibble column named "variable" (variable ID). value "variable" must unique. set "variable" values must match row names expression matrix (order matter). function automatically reorder expression matrix match order "sample" "variable" info tables.

title: Create a new experiment ‚Äî experiment
text: columns required compulsorily variable information tibble valid experiment. depends experiment type. "glycomics": glycan_composition. "glycoproteomics": protein, protein_site, glycan_composition. "traitomics": required columns. "traitproteomics": protein, protein_site. "others": required columns. See "Column conventions" section detailed description columns. last two types experiments created glydet package. Normally need manually create .

title: Create a new experiment ‚Äî experiment
text: glycoverse conserved column names sample_info var_info make everything work seamlessly. mandatory, following conventions make life easier. sample_info: group: factor, treatment/condition/grouping, used many glystats glyvis functions. batch: factor, batch information, used glyclean::correct_batch_effect(). bio_rep: factor, biological replicate, may used future. var_info: protein: character, protein Uniprot accession. protein_site: integer, glycosylation site position protein. gene: character, gene symbol. peptide: character, peptide sequence. peptide_site: integer, glycosylation site position peptide. glycan_composition: glyrepr::glycan_composition(), glycan composition. glycan_structure: glyrepr::glycan_structure(), glycan structure.

title: Create a new experiment ‚Äî experiment
text: meta data can added meta_data attribute. meta_data list additional information experiment. Two meta data fields required: exp_type: "glycomics", "glycoproteomics", "traitomics", "traitproteomics", "others" glycan_type: "N" "O" (can NULL exp_type "others") meta data added glycoverse packages purposes.

title: Create a new experiment ‚Äî experiment
text: index columns backbone keep data synchronized: "sample" column sample_info must match column names expr_mat. "variable" column var_info must match row names expr_mat. columns act unique identifiers, ensuring expression matrix, sample information, variable information always stay sync, matter filter, arrange, subset data.

title: Create a new experiment ‚Äî experiment
code: # The minimum required input is an expression matrix. expr_mat <- matrix(runif(9), nrow = 3, ncol = 3) colnames(expr_mat) <- c("S1", "S2", "S3") rownames(expr_mat) <- c("V1", "V2", "V3") experiment(expr_mat) #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Others Experiment ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ #> ‚Ñπ Expression matrix: 3 samples, 3 variables #> ‚Ñπ Sample information fields: none #> ‚Ñπ Variable information fields: none  # Or with more detailed information. sample_info <- tibble::tibble(sample = c("S1", "S2", "S3"), group = c("A", "B", "A")) var_info <- tibble::tibble(   variable = c("V1", "V2", "V3"),   glycan_composition = glyrepr::glycan_composition(c(Hex = 1)) ) experiment(expr_mat, sample_info, var_info, exp_type = "glycomics", glycan_type = "N") #> Column group converted to <factor>. #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Glycomics Experiment ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ #> ‚Ñπ Expression matrix: 3 samples, 3 variables #> ‚Ñπ Sample information fields: group <fct> #> ‚Ñπ Variable information fields: glycan_composition <comp>

what: glyexp: Glycoproteomics and Glycomics Experiments ‚Äî glyexp-package
title: glyexp: Glycoproteomics and Glycomics Experiments ‚Äî glyexp-package
text: Provides tidy data framework managing glycoproteomics glycomics experimental data. core feature 'experiment()' class, serves unified data container integrating expression matrices, variable information (proteins, peptides, glycan compositions, etc.), sample metadata (groups, batches, clinical variables, etc.). package enforces data consistency, validates column types according experiment types (glycomics, glycoproteomics, traitomics, traitproteomics), provides dplyr-style data manipulation functions (filter, mutate, select, arrange, slice, join) seamless data wrangling. data core 'glycoverse' ecosystem, provides consistent interface packages can reliably extract information , enabling smooth data exchange analysis workflows.

title: glyexp: Glycoproteomics and Glycomics Experiments ‚Äî glyexp-package
text: Maintainer: Bin Fu 23110220018@m.fudan.edu.cn (ORCID)

title: Join data to sample or variable information ‚Äî left_join_obs
code: library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: ‚Äòdplyr‚Äô #> The following object is masked from ‚Äòpackage:glyexp‚Äô: #>  #>     select_var #> The following objects are masked from ‚Äòpackage:stats‚Äô: #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from ‚Äòpackage:base‚Äô: #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union library(tibble)  # Create a toy experiment exp <- toy_experiment  # Create additional sample information to join extra_sample_info <- tibble(   sample = c("S1", "S2", "S3", "S4"),   age = c(25, 30, 35, 40),   treatment = c("A", "B", "A", "B") )  # Left join to sample information exp_with_extra <- left_join_obs(exp, extra_sample_info, by = "sample") get_sample_info(exp_with_extra) #> # A tibble: 6 √ó 5 #>   sample group batch   age treatment #>   <chr>  <chr> <dbl> <dbl> <chr>     #> 1 S1     A         1    25 A         #> 2 S2     A         2    30 B         #> 3 S3     A         1    35 A         #> 4 S4     B         2    40 B         #> 5 S5     B         1    NA NA        #> 6 S6     B         2    NA NA         # Inner join (only keeps matching samples) exp_inner <- inner_join_obs(exp, extra_sample_info, by = "sample") get_sample_info(exp_inner) #> # A tibble: 4 √ó 5 #>   sample group batch   age treatment #>   <chr>  <chr> <dbl> <dbl> <chr>     #> 1 S1     A         1    25 A         #> 2 S2     A         2    30 B         #> 3 S3     A         1    35 A         #> 4 S4     B         2    40 B         get_expr_mat(exp_inner)  # Note: expr_mat is updated too #>    S1 S2 S3 S4 #> V1  1  5  9 13 #> V2  2  6 10 14 #> V3  3  7 11 15 #> V4  4  8 12 16  # Create additional variable information to join extra_var_info <- tibble(   protein = c("P1", "P2", "P3"),   pathway = c("A", "B", "A"),   importance = c(0.8, 0.6, 0.9) )  # Left join to variable information exp_with_var_extra <- left_join_var(exp, extra_var_info, by = "protein") get_var_info(exp_with_var_extra) #> # A tibble: 4 √ó 6 #>   variable protein peptide glycan_composition pathway importance #>   <chr>    <chr>   <chr>   <chr>              <chr>        <dbl> #> 1 V1       PRO1    PEP1    H5N2               NA              NA #> 2 V2       PRO2    PEP2    H5N2               NA              NA #> 3 V3       PRO3    PEP3    H3N2               NA              NA #> 4 V4       PRO3    PEP4    H3N2               NA              NA

title: Merge two experiments ‚Äî merge.glyexp_experiment
text: Merges two experiment() objects single object. Expression matrix: Expression matrices merged matching variables. variables present one experiments, corresponding values expression matrix set NA. Sample information: Column names column types must identical (order matter). overlap allowed sample names. Variable information: Column names column types must identical (order matter). Variable names ignored. identity variables determined columns variable information. row first var_info identical (order matter) row B second var_info, considered variable. Therefore, please make sure row unique combination values (except variable), otherwise function determine variable x identical variable y. ensure uniqueness, can use glyclean::aggregate(). Metadata: Metadata taken first experiment. place order x y matters.

title: Real glycoproteomics experiment ‚Äî real_experiment
text: real glycoproteomics experiment object. dataset derived unpublished ProteomeXchange dataset PXD063749. contains serum N-glycoproteome profiles 12 patients different liver conditions: healthy (H), hepatitis (M), cirrhosis (Y), hepatocellular carcinoma (C). Glycopeptide identification annotation performed using pGlyco3 (https://github.com/pFindStudio/pGlyco3), quantification carried pGlycoQuant (https://github.com/Power-Quant/pGlycoQuant). raw data imported glyread::read_pglyco3_pglycoquant().
